subject: Re: adding rudimentary timing to a TestCase via a TestDecorator
msgSnippet: Thanks! I currently have these two classes: public class TimedTest extends TestSetup { // Class that extends a TestCase to provide basic timestamp logging long
messageBody:
Thanks!

I currently have these two classes:

public class TimedTest extends TestSetup {
// Class that extends a TestCase to provide basic timestamp logging
long m_lStart, m_lEnd;

public TimedTest ( Test t ) {
super ( t );
}

protected void setUp ( ) throws Exception {
this.m_lStart = System.currentTimeMillis ( );
System.out.println ( "Beginning at: " + this.m_lStart );
}

protected void tearDown ( ) throws Exception {
this.m_lEnd = System.currentTimeMillis ( );
System.out.println ( "Ending at: " + this.m_lEnd );
System.out.println ( "Elapsed: " +
( this.m_lEnd - this.m_lStart ) );
}
}

public class FooTimedTest extends FooTest {
// Where FooTest is an arbitrary TestCase class
public static Test suite ( ){
TestSuite testSuite = new TestSuite();
// Add two tests to the suite, add timestamp logging to each
testSuite.addTest( new TimedTest (
new FooTest( "testFirstMethod" ) );
// etc
}
}

Sample output:
Beginning at: 832421341
Beginning at: 832421341
Beginning at: 832421341
Entering FooTest.testFirstMethod
Yup, it works
Exiting FooTest.testFirstMethod
Ending at: 832422981
Ending at: 832422981
Ending at: 832422981
Elapsed: 840
Elapsed: 840
Elapsed: 840

It functions fairly well, printing the timestamps at the appropriate
places, but the problem I've had is that it does it multiple times --
printing out the same log statement two or three times, even though
only one test is being run. Multiple setUp and tearDown calls, it
seems.

I would prefer to use a TestDecorator, but I have yet to find a
decent example of how to use them.

Your help is greatly appreciated!

Thanks
Mark Huisman
